channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Mirror-image molecules separated using workhorse of chemistry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00384-2

The ability to distinguish between left- and right-handed molecules using mass spectrometry could streamline a laborious part of drug discovery.
item.dc:title: Mirror-image molecules separated using workhorse of chemistry
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Why an ancient gold-based explosive makes purple smoke
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00316-0

Gold nanoparticles are confirmed as the source of the flamboyant colour of the smoke produced by fulminating gold.
item.dc:title: Why an ancient gold-based explosive makes purple smoke

item.title: Author Correction: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from Mexico City
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07051-6

Author Correction: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from Mexico City
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from Mexico City

item.title: US and China likely to delay renewal of key science pact again
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00380-6

Relations have changed between the two nations, so negotiators are hashing out new terms in the 45-year-old agreement.
item.dc:title: US and China likely to delay renewal of key science pact again
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert
Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: How to test a Moon landing from Earth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00352-w

The world is racing to land on the Moon. How do space agencies and commercial companies test their landers ahead of time?
item.dc:title: How to test a Moon landing from Earth
item.dc:creator: Jatan Mehta

item.title: Why a cheap, effective treatment for diarrhoea is underused
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00351-x

Actors posing as dads of sick children reveal the hidden motives behind doctors’ and pharmacists’ prescription decisions.
item.dc:title: Why a cheap, effective treatment for diarrhoea is underused
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Cancer’s power harnessed — lymphoma mutations supercharge T cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00379-z

Genetic changes that help tumour cells thrive can be co-opted to improve immunotherapy’s effectiveness, and looking at the electric vehicle batteries of the future.
item.dc:title: Cancer’s power harnessed — lymphoma mutations supercharge T cells
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Circulating myeloid-derived MMP8 in stress susceptibility and depression
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07015-2

Serum MMP8 is increased in stress-susceptible mice following chronic stress and leads to brain structure and behavioural changes in mice.
item.dc:title: Circulating myeloid-derived MMP8 in stress susceptibility and depression
item.dc:creator: Flurin Cathomas
Hsiao-Yun Lin

Scott J. Russo

item.title: Identification of direct connections between the dura and the brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06993-7

Arachnoid cuff exit points create openings in the arachnoid barrier enabling the drainage of cerebrospinal fluid and exchange of molecules and cells between the dura and the subarachnoid space, therefore physically connecting the brain and the dura.
item.dc:title: Identification of direct connections between the dura and the brain
item.dc:creator: Leon C. D. Smyth
Di Xu
Serhat V. Okar

Jonathan Kipnis

item.title: Naturally occurring T cell mutations enhance engineered T cell therapies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07018-7

A study examines the effects of mutations that occur naturally in T cell cancers, reporting that such mutations can potentially be exploited to increase the potency of T cell therapies.
item.dc:title: Naturally occurring T cell mutations enhance engineered T cell therapies
item.dc:creator: Julie Garcia
Jay Daniels
Yujin Lee
Iowis Zhu
Kathleen Cheng
Qing Liu
Daniel Goodman
Cassandra Burnett
Calvin Law
Chloë Thienpont
Josef Alavi
Camillia Azimi
Garrett Montgomery
Kole T. Roybal
Jaehyuk Choi

item.title: A break in mitochondrial endosymbiosis as a basis for inflammatory diseases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06866-z

We suggest that as mitochondrial signals probably contribute to the homeostatic role of inflammation, dysregulation of these processes may lead to autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, with increasing evidence pointing to the recent failure of endosymbiosis being crucial.
item.dc:title: A break in mitochondrial endosymbiosis as a basis for inflammatory diseases
item.dc:creator: Michael P. Murphy
Luke A. J. O’Neill

item.title: Light-driven nanoscale vectorial currents
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07037-4

Vectorial optoelectronic metasurfaces are described, showing that light pulses can be used to drive and direct local charge flows around symmetry-broken plasmonic nanostructures, leading to tunable responses in terahertz emission.
item.dc:title: Light-driven nanoscale vectorial currents
item.dc:creator: Jacob Pettine
Prashant Padmanabhan
Teng Shi
Lauren Gingras
Luke McClintock
Chun-Chieh Chang
Kevin W. C. Kwock
Long Yuan

Antoinette J. Taylor
Rohit P. Prasankumar
Shi-Zeng Lin
Hou-Tong Chen

item.title: Elevated Southern Hemisphere moisture availability during glacial periods
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06989-3

Contrary to expectations from pollen and dust records, Southern Hemisphere subtropical regions experienced the greatest climatic moisture during glacial periods of the Late Pleistocene, which may not have been an obstacle to movement and expansion of animals and plants.
item.dc:title: Elevated Southern Hemisphere moisture availability during glacial periods
item.dc:creator: Rieneke Weij
J. M. Kale Sniderman
Jon D. Woodhead
John C. Hellstrom
Josephine R. Brown
Russell N. Drysdale
Elizabeth Reed
Steven Bourne
Jay Gordon

item.title: Evidence of superconducting Fermi arcs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06977-7

We provide evidence for superconducting topological Fermi arcs in PbBi2—a Weyl semimetal previously studied mostly for its bulk properties—from which Marjorama fermions could be derived for research in quantum computers.
item.dc:title: Evidence of superconducting Fermi arcs
item.dc:creator: Andrii Kuibarov
Oleksandr Suvorov
Riccardo Vocaturo
Alexander Fedorov
Rui Lou
Luise Merkwitz
Vladimir Voroshnin
Jorge I. Facio

Grigory Shipunov
Saicharan Aswartham
Jeroen van den Brink
Bernd Büchner
Sergey Borisenko

item.title: Converting an allocentric goal into an egocentric steering signal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07006-3

In Drosophila, FC2 neurons signal a navigational goal, which is compared with the fly’s heading by PFL3 neurons to guide moment-to-moment steering.
item.dc:title: Converting an allocentric goal into an egocentric steering signal
item.dc:creator: Peter Mussells Pires
Lingwei Zhang
Victoria Parache
L. F. Abbott
Gaby Maimon

item.title: A rechargeable calcium–oxygen battery that operates at room temperature
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06949-x

A Ca–O2 battery that relies on a highly reversible two-electron redox to form chemically reactive calcium peroxide as the discharge product is reported to be stable in air and rechargeable for 700 cycles at room temperature.
item.dc:title: A rechargeable calcium–oxygen battery that operates at room temperature
item.dc:creator: Lei Ye
Meng Liao
Kun Zhang
Mengting Zheng
Yi Jiang
Xiangran Cheng

item.title: A recently formed ocean inside Saturn’s moon Mimas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06975-9

An analysis of the orbital motion of Saturn’s moon Mimas shows that a recently formed global subsurface ocean lies beneath its cratered icy shell and that this ocean is probably still evolving.
item.dc:title: A recently formed ocean inside Saturn’s moon Mimas
item.dc:creator: V. Lainey
N. Rambaux
G. Tobie
N. Cooper
Q. Zhang
B. Noyelles
K. Baillié

item.title: Spatial transcriptomics reveal neuron–astrocyte synergy in long-term memory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07011-6

Spatial and single-cell transcriptomic analyses of the mouse basolateral amygdala reveal transcriptomic signatures, spatial resolution and interactions of cells that constitute the memory engram, including crucial neuron–astrocyte interactions.
item.dc:title: Spatial transcriptomics reveal neuron–astrocyte synergy in long-term memory
item.dc:creator: Wenfei Sun
Zhihui Liu
Xian Jiang
Michelle B. Chen
Hua Dong
Jonathan Liu
Thomas C. Südhof
Stephen R. Quake

item.title: Signatures of a surface spin–orbital chiral metal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07033-8

A spin–orbital- and angular-momentum-sensitive methodology used to study Sr2RuO4 reveals subtle spectroscopic signatures that are consistent with the formation of spin–orbital chiral currents at the surface of the material.
item.dc:title: Signatures of a surface spin–orbital chiral metal
item.dc:creator: Federico Mazzola
Wojciech Brzezicki
Maria Teresa Mercaldo
Anita Guarino
Chiara Bigi
Jill A. Miwa

item.title: Translation selectively destroys non-functional transcription complexes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07014-3

Translation actively dislodges stalled transcription elongation complexes (ECs) from damaged DNA, which enables lesion repair and restoration of transcription activity, and coupled ribosomes discriminate between active ECs and stalled ECs, ensuring destruction of only the latter.
item.dc:title: Translation selectively destroys non-functional transcription complexes
item.dc:creator: Jason Woodgate
Hamed Mosaei
Pavel Brazda
Flint Stevenson-Jones
Nikolay Zenkin

item.title: Recovery of isolated lithium through discharged state calendar ageing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06992-8

Calendar ageing of lithium metal batteries in the discharged state improves capacity retention through isolated lithium recovery, which is in contrast with the capacity degradation observed during charged state calendar ageing.
item.dc:title: Recovery of isolated lithium through discharged state calendar ageing
item.dc:creator: Wenbo Zhang
Philaphon Sayavong
Xin Xiao
Solomon T. Oyakhire
Sanzeeda Baig Shuchi
Rafael A. Vilá

Sarah E. Holmes
Yusheng Ye
Donglin Li
Stacey F. Bent
Yi Cui

item.title: Bile salt hydrolase acyltransferase activity expands bile acid diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07017-8

Acyltransferase activity of the enzyme bile salt hydrolase is identified and shown to mediate microbial bile acid conjugation, diversifying the bile acid pool and expanding their role in gut physiology.
item.dc:title: Bile salt hydrolase acyltransferase activity expands bile acid diversity
item.dc:creator: Douglas V. Guzior
Maxwell Okros
Madison Shivel
Bruin Armwald

Robert A. Quinn

item.title: Observation and quantification of the pseudogap in unitary Fermi gases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06964-y

This study describes experiments with ultracold lithium Fermi gases in which many-body pairing leads to the emergence of a pseudogap, and it confirms theoretical predictions relevant to cuprate superconductivity.
item.dc:title: Observation and quantification of the pseudogap in unitary Fermi gases
item.dc:creator: Xi Li
Shuai Wang

item.title: Allosteric modulation and G-protein selectivity of the Ca<sup>2+</sup>-sensing receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07055-2

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the human calcium-sensing receptor in complex with Gi and Gq proteins reveal how this receptor activates distinct G protein subtypes and how its function is modulated by a variety of ligands.
item.dc:title: Allosteric modulation and G-protein selectivity of the Ca<sup>2+</sup>-sensing receptor
item.dc:creator: Feng He
Cheng-Guo Wu
Yang Gao
Sabrina N. Rahman

Lingjun Li
Jesper M. Mathiesen
Georgios Skiniotis

item.title: Bile salt hydrolase catalyses formation of amine-conjugated bile acids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06990-w

We find that bile salt hydrolase N-acyltransferase activity can form bacterial bile acid amidates that are positively correlated with the colonization of gut bacteria that assist in the regulation of the bile acid metabolic network.
item.dc:title: Bile salt hydrolase catalyses formation of amine-conjugated bile acids
item.dc:creator: Bipin Rimal

item.title: Transforming a head direction signal into a goal-oriented steering command
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07039-2

Here we show how PFL2 and PFL3 neurons in the Drosophila brain compare a representation of direction with internal spatial goals, both anchored in world-centric coordinates, and produce body-centric steering commands that act to correct deviations from the goal direction.
item.dc:title: Transforming a head direction signal into a goal-oriented steering command
item.dc:creator: Elena A. Westeinde
Emily Kellogg
Paul M. Dawson
Jenny Lu
Lydia Hamburg
Benjamin Midler
Shaul Druckmann
Rachel I. Wilson

item.title: The nuclear factor ID3 endows macrophages with a potent anti-tumour activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06950-4

The Kupffer cell lineage-determining factor ID3 selectively endows macrophages with the ability to phagocytose live tumour cells and orchestrate the recruitment, proliferation and activation of natural killer and CD8+ T lymphoid effector cells to restrict the growth of a variety of tumours.
item.dc:title: The nuclear factor ID3 endows macrophages with a potent anti-tumour activity
item.dc:creator: Zihou Deng

Frederic Geissmann

item.title: Convergence of coronary artery disease genes onto endothelial cell programs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07022-x

Variant-to-gene-to-program is a new approach to building maps of genome function to link risk variants to disease genes and to convergent signalling pathways in an unbiased manner; its strength is demonstrated in coronary artery disease.
item.dc:title: Convergence of coronary artery disease genes onto endothelial cell programs
item.dc:creator: Gavin R. Schnitzler

item.title: Structural basis of ribosomal 30S subunit degradation by RNase R
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07027-6

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of intermediates formed during the degradation of the 30S ribosomal unit shed light on how the 3′ to 5′ exonuclease ribonuclease R controls the ribosomal degradation process.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of ribosomal 30S subunit degradation by RNase R
item.dc:creator: Lyudmila Dimitrova-Paternoga
Sergo Kasvandik
Bertrand Beckert
Sander Granneman
Tanel Tenson
Daniel N. Wilson
Helge Paternoga

item.title: A distinct cortical code for socially learned threat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07008-1

Studies in mice show that observational fear learning is encoded by neurons in the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex in a manner that is distinct from the encoding of fear learned by direct experience.
item.dc:title: A distinct cortical code for socially learned threat
item.dc:creator: Shana E. Silverstein

item.title: Could roving researchers help address the challenge of taking parental leave?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00354-8

Institutions are taking notice of a handful of programmes designed to address the issues scientists face when choosing to take a long-term absence.
item.dc:title: Could roving researchers help address the challenge of taking parental leave?
item.dc:creator: Amy Coombs

item.title: Mimas’s surprise ocean prompts an update of the rule book for moons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00194-6

The shifting orbit of one of Saturn’s moons indicates that the satellite has a subsurface ocean, contradicting theories that its interior is entirely solid. The finding calls for a fresh take on what constitutes an ocean moon.
item.dc:title: Mimas’s surprise ocean prompts an update of the rule book for moons
item.dc:creator: Matija Ćuk
Alyssa Rose Rhoden

item.title: Turbocharged CAR-T cells melt tumours in mice — using a trick from cancer cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00305-3

Immune cells armed with a mutation first identified in cancer cells gain potency but don’t turn cancerous themselves.
item.dc:title: Turbocharged CAR-T cells melt tumours in mice — using a trick from cancer cells
item.dc:creator: Asher Mullard

item.title: Turing test — all my broken hearts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00331-1

A chance encounter.
item.dc:title: Turing test — all my broken hearts
item.dc:creator: Gareth Owens

item.title: The Solar System has a new ocean — it’s buried in a small Saturn moon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00345-9

The sea inside Saturn’s satellite Mimas formed in the past 25 million years, a blink of the eye in geological terms.
item.dc:title: The Solar System has a new ocean — it’s buried in a small Saturn moon
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Daily briefing: Santorini volcano let off a prehistoric mega-blast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00386-0

An expedition that drilled into the sea floor near the Greek island discovered signs of a huge eruption more than half a million years ago. Plus, the ambitious EU climate strategy and how self-propelled fluids play sudoku.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Santorini volcano let off a prehistoric mega-blast
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: A neural circuit for navigation keeps flies on target
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00230-5

Studies reveal how neuronal populations in the fruit fly brain work together to compare the direction of a goal with the direction that the fly is facing, and convert this into a signal that steers the fly towards its target.
item.dc:title: A neural circuit for navigation keeps flies on target
item.dc:creator: Katherine Nagel

item.title: How my academic sabbatical offered a chance to hit the restart button on my career
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00381-5

Time away from his daily responsibilities taught Brandon Brown that he is replaceable — and that’s a good thing.
item.dc:title: How my academic sabbatical offered a chance to hit the restart button on my career
item.dc:creator: Brandon Brown

item.title: The new car batteries that could power the electric vehicle revolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00325-z

Researchers are experimenting with different designs that could lower costs, extend vehicle ranges and offer other improvements.
item.dc:title: The new car batteries that could power the electric vehicle revolution
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Fake research papers flagged by analysing authorship trends
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00344-w

A new approach to detecting fraudulent paper-mill studies focuses on patterns of co-authors rather than manuscript text.
item.dc:title: Fake research papers flagged by analysing authorship trends
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Cyberattacks on knowledge institutions are increasing: what can be done?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00323-1

For months, ransomware attacks have debilitated research at the British Library in London and Berlin’s natural history museum. They show how vulnerable scientific and educational institutions are to this kind of crime.
item.dc:title: Cyberattacks on knowledge institutions are increasing: what can be done?

item.title: Resting restores performance of discharged lithium-metal batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00229-y

In lithium-metal batteries, grains of lithium can become electrically isolated from the anode, lowering battery performance. Experiments reveal that rest periods after battery discharge might help to solve this problem.
item.dc:title: Resting restores performance of discharged lithium-metal batteries
item.dc:creator: Laura C. Merrill

item.title: Best practice for LGBTQ+ data collection by STEM organizations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00298-z

Best practice for LGBTQ+ data collection by STEM organizations
item.dc:title: Best practice for LGBTQ+ data collection by STEM organizations
item.dc:creator: Alexander L. Bond
Tyler L. Kelly

item.title: Urban trees: how to maximize their benefits for humans and the environment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00300-8

Urban trees: how to maximize their benefits for humans and the environment
item.dc:title: Urban trees: how to maximize their benefits for humans and the environment
item.dc:creator: Lina Tang
Guofan Shao
Peter M. Groffman

item.title: From the archive: lonely cells, and Thomas Henry Huxley backs evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00235-0

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: lonely cells, and Thomas Henry Huxley backs evolution

item.title: ‘Bee protection’ offsets are as flawed as tree-planting schemes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00299-y

‘Bee protection’ offsets are as flawed as tree-planting schemes
item.dc:title: ‘Bee protection’ offsets are as flawed as tree-planting schemes
item.dc:creator: Ainhoa Magrach

item.title: Clinical trials: Japan’s opt-out policy raises risks of adverse drug responses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00301-7

Clinical trials: Japan’s opt-out policy raises risks of adverse drug responses
item.dc:title: Clinical trials: Japan’s opt-out policy raises risks of adverse drug responses
item.dc:creator: Mira Namba
Yudai Kaneda
Akihiko Ozaki
Tetsuya Tanimoto

item.title: ‘Altruistic’ bull elephant seal lends a helping flipper
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00319-x

Male elephant seals generally have nothing to do with pups — but astounded scientists observed a notable exception.
item.dc:title: ‘Altruistic’ bull elephant seal lends a helping flipper

item.title: Santorini’s volcanic past: underwater clues reveal giant prehistoric eruption
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00326-y

An expedition that drilled into the sea floor near the famous Greek island found signs of a gargantuan blast 520,000 years ago and more recent eruptions.
item.dc:title: Santorini’s volcanic past: underwater clues reveal giant prehistoric eruption
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: EU unveils controversial climate target: what scientists think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00361-9

The goal leans heavily on the largely unproven approach of carbon removal, concerning researchers.
item.dc:title: EU unveils controversial climate target: what scientists think
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson
Carissa Wong

item.title: Why the mental cost of a STEM career can be too high for women and people of colour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00324-0

Under-represented groups face chronic barriers, creating psychological — and physical — effects. The scientific community must ease this burden.
item.dc:title: Why the mental cost of a STEM career can be too high for women and people of colour
item.dc:creator: Jean King

item.title: Active fluids navigate networks by solving sudoku-like problems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00277-4

Networks filled with self-propelled fluids display meandering patterns that have been shown to follow rules similar to those of sudoku puzzles — offering design principles for microfluidic devices, and the possibility of ‘active fluid’ logic.
item.dc:title: Active fluids navigate networks by solving sudoku-like problems
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Le Verge-Serandour
Karen Alim

item.title: No ‘easy’ weight loss: don’t overlook the social cost of anti-obesity drugs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00329-9

Ideas of diet and exercise as the ‘best’ way to lose weight could stigmatize people taking Ozempic, WeGovy and other blockbuster drugs that affect appetite. Lessons from weight-loss surgery reveal ways to help.
item.dc:title: No ‘easy’ weight loss: don’t overlook the social cost of anti-obesity drugs
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Brewis
Sarah Trainer

item.title: Open science — embrace it before it’s too late
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00322-2

A UNESCO report laments the lack of progress in making science more collaborative. Greater awareness could aid efforts to achieve the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals.
item.dc:title: Open science — embrace it before it’s too late

item.title: Economists count the cost of ‘risky’ science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00360-w

A survey seeks to define risk in research and how academics approach it in their work.
item.dc:title: Economists count the cost of ‘risky’ science
item.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

item.title: CERN’s supercollider plan: $17-billion ‘Higgs factory’ would dwarf LHC
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00353-9

A feasibility study on the Future Circular Collider identifies where and how the machine could be built — but its construction is far from a done deal.
item.dc:title: CERN’s supercollider plan: $17-billion ‘Higgs factory’ would dwarf LHC
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney
Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: Lack of transparency surrounds Neuralink’s ‘brain-reading’ chip
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00375-3

What scientists think of brain-computer interface company Neuralink’s first human trial. Plus, an AI system learnt language by seeing the world through a baby’s eyes and how ChatGPT could sway climate-change deniers.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: Lack of transparency surrounds Neuralink’s ‘brain-reading’ chip
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: How population size shapes the evolution of guppy fish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00276-5

A long-term fish experiment reveals how a mechanism called density dependence, in which the population growth rate slows as the number of individuals rises, affects population dynamics on time scales relevant for ecology and evolution.
item.dc:title: How population size shapes the evolution of guppy fish
item.dc:creator: Bernt-Erik Sæther

item.title: Absence of female partners can explain the dawn chorus of birds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00264-9

Why birds sing intensely in a dawn chorus during the early morning has long been debated. Evidence gathered from observing birds in the wild offers a fresh perspective on what might drive this phenomenon.
item.dc:title: Absence of female partners can explain the dawn chorus of birds
item.dc:creator: Diego Gil

item.title: AI chatbot shows surprising talent for predicting chemical properties and reactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00347-7

Researchers lightly tweak ChatGPT-like system to offer chemistry insight.
item.dc:title: AI chatbot shows surprising talent for predicting chemical properties and reactions
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Daily briefing: 300-year-old sponges show 1.5 °C warming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00366-4

Evidence from marine sponges suggests that the planet has already passed global warming milestone. Plus, text revealed from inside a scroll burnt by Vesuvius and record demand for JWST telescope time.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: 300-year-old sponges show 1.5 °C warming
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Ivory artefacts’ origins revealed by telltale peptides
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00247-w

The family, genus or even species of animal that supplied the materials for a famed museum’s objects could be identified with minimal damage to the items.
item.dc:title: Ivory artefacts’ origins revealed by telltale peptides

item.title: The brain area that lights up in prickly people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00318-y

Those who are quick to take offence show similar levels of activity in a region of the brain that’s crucial for decision-making.
item.dc:title: The brain area that lights up in prickly people

item.title: Surprise find: a blood-based immune system is discovered in the gut
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00245-y

Immune guardians called complement proteins are manufactured by gut cells and help to protect against pathogens.
item.dc:title: Surprise find: a blood-based immune system is discovered in the gut

item.title: I started fossil hunting in my 60s — now I have more than 2,000 pieces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00330-2

Heather Middleton trawls England’s Jurassic Coast for specimens that might lead to a deeper understanding of palaeontology.
item.dc:title: I started fossil hunting in my 60s — now I have more than 2,000 pieces
item.dc:creator: Rachael Pells

item.title: Synthesizing and identifying potential biomarkers to explore uncharted biochemistry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04105-z

Public repositories of metabolomics data are expanding rapidly and can be leveraged to uncover previously undescribed metabolites. Reverse metabolomics is a workflow in which thousands of small compounds are synthesized using combinatorial chemistry, and their molecular ‘fingerprints’ are then used to discover where they are localized in tissues and biological fluids and how they are associated with health and disease in humans.
item.dc:title: Synthesizing and identifying potential biomarkers to explore uncharted biochemistry

item.title: The world has warmed 1.5 °C, according to 300-year-old sponges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00281-8

By the time that official temperature records began, global temperatures had already risen by half a degree.
item.dc:title: The world has warmed 1.5 °C, according to 300-year-old sponges
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: JWST is most in-demand telescope ever — leaving many astronomers in the cold
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00315-1

Reviewers will probably approve only one in every nine research proposals submitted in latest application cycle.
item.dc:title: JWST is most in-demand telescope ever — leaving many astronomers in the cold
item.dc:creator: Rahul Rao

item.title: Innovative funding systems are key to fighting inequities in African science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00348-6

A few countries and a select number of institutions will continue to take the vast majority of grants unless funders build diversity into their grant programmes.
item.dc:title: Innovative funding systems are key to fighting inequities in African science
item.dc:creator: Susan Gichoga

item.title: It’s time to admit that genes are not the blueprint for life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00327-x

The view of biology often presented to the public is oversimplified and out of date. Scientists must set the record straight, argues a new book.
item.dc:title: It’s time to admit that genes are not the blueprint for life
item.dc:creator: Denis Noble

item.title: Several transient binding events create a strong, adaptable interface between organelles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04120-0

Rapid communication between intracellular structures such as the endoplasmic reticulum and the mitochondria is crucial for the coordinated functioning of cells. Such interactions occur mainly at sites where the compartments are in direct contact, and are mediated by specific tethering machinery. High-speed single-molecule tracking reveals a well-regulated interface at which many rapid binding and unbinding events provide highly adaptable interactions.
item.dc:title: Several transient binding events create a strong, adaptable interface between organelles

item.title: First passages of rolled-up Herculaneum scroll revealed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00346-8

Researchers used artificial intelligence to decipher the text of 2,000-year-old charred papyrus scripts, unveiling musings on music and capers.
item.dc:title: First passages of rolled-up Herculaneum scroll revealed
item.dc:creator: Jo Marchant

item.title: ‘Obviously ChatGPT’ — how reviewers accused me of scientific fraud
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00349-5

A journal reviewer accused Lizzie Wolkovich of using ChatGPT to write a manuscript. She hadn’t — but her paper was rejected anyway.
item.dc:title: ‘Obviously ChatGPT’ — how reviewers accused me of scientific fraud
item.dc:creator: E. M. Wolkovich

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Feynman’s sprinkler’ spin mystery solved
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00356-6

If an S-shaped sprinkler sucks instead of sprays, which way does it spin? Plus, the month’s best science images and what scientists think of the Neuralink human trial.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Feynman’s sprinkler’ spin mystery solved
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Science and government: can the power struggle ever end?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00328-w

Similar goals but different strategies underlie tensions between science and the state, an in-depth analysis explains.
item.dc:title: Science and government: can the power struggle ever end?
item.dc:creator: Rhona Mijumbi
